user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_bind:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_bind(struct linux_device *ldev,
			      struct linux_driver *ldrv)
{
	struct sysfs_attribute *attr;
	int result;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, ldrv->drv_name) == 0)
		return 0;

	if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, SYSFS_UNKNOWN) != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO, "device %s in use by driver %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldev->sdev->driver_name);
		return -EBUSY;
	}

	attr = sysfs_get_device_attr(ldev->sdev, "driver_override");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s has no override\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldrv->drv_name,
				       strlen(ldrv->drv_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to set override on %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name);
		return -errno;
	}
	ldev->override = attr;

	attr = sysfs_get_driver_attr(ldrv->sdrv, "bind");
	if (!attr) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "driver %s has no bind\n", ldrv->drv_name);
		return -ENOTSUP;
	}

	result = sysfs_write_attribute(attr, ldev->dev_name,
				       strlen(ldev->dev_name));
	if (result) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to bind %s to %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);
		return -errno;
	}

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "bound device %s to driver %s\n",
		  ldev->dev_name, ldrv->drv_name);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_bind:
struct linux_device {
	struct metal_device		device;
	char				dev_name[PATH_MAX];
	char				dev_path[PATH_MAX];
	char				cls_path[PATH_MAX];
	metal_phys_addr_t		region_phys[METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS];
	struct linux_driver		*ldrv;
	struct sysfs_device		*sdev;
	struct sysfs_attribute		*override;
	int				fd;
}
...
struct linux_driver {
	const char		*drv_name;
	const char		*mod_name;
	const char		*cls_name;
	struct sysfs_driver	*sdrv;
	int			(*dev_open)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					    struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_close)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev);
	void			(*dev_irq_ack)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
					     struct linux_device *ldev,
					     int irq);
	int			(*dev_dma_map)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg_in,
						int nents_in,
						struct metal_sg *sg_out);
	void			(*dev_dma_unmap)(struct linux_bus *lbus,
						struct linux_device *ldev,
						uint32_t dir,
						struct metal_sg *sg,
						int nents);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that are invariant. The function contains only if statements whose controlling expressions depend on runtime values or function returns:

- if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, ldrv->drv_name) == 0)
  - strcmp() is evaluated at runtime and depends on the two string values.

- if (strcmp(ldev->sdev->driver_name, SYSFS_UNKNOWN) != 0)
  - Although SYSFS_UNKNOWN is a constant, the comparison depends on ldev->sdev->driver_name at runtime.

- if (!attr) (two occurrences)
  - attr is assigned from sysfs_get_device_attr() (or sysfs_get_driver_attr()), which returns a runtime value.

- if (result) (two occurrences)
  - result is assigned from sysfs_write_attribute(), whose return value is determined at runtime.

There are no loop constructs (for, while, do-while) whose controlling expressions could be invariant, and none of the allowed exceptions (infinite loops or the specific do-while integer-constant case) apply. Therefore, no code fragments need to be investigated for violations of MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
